Organs/Tissues: Human liver parenchyma (hepatocytes) in microfluidic wells
Physiological/Pathological: Normal liver metabolism; can model drug-induced liver injury, steatosis
Cell Source: Primary human hepatocytes or iPSC-derived hepatic cells, co-cultures possible
Multiple Cell Types: Yes if including non-parenchymal liver cells (stellate, Kupffer) or typically at least hepatocytes
Stromal Cells: Optional; can add stellate cells for fibrosis studies
Tissue-resident Immune: Possible if Kupffer cells are co-cultured, not standard by default
Circulating Immune: No (unless introduced in a multi-organ circuit or advanced model)
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, can link to other organ chips on PREDICT96 if desired
Extracellular Matrix: Collagen or Matrigel in 3D microchambers or membrane-based culture
3D Scaffold: Yes, 3D hepatic microtissues or sandwich cultures under flow
Notable Features: Metabolic function, drug toxicity screening under perfusion, integrated TEER sensors, small-volume recirculation
Plate/Format (Throughput): PREDICT96 plate – 96 wells with microfluidic flow, mid–high throughput
Max Culture Duration: Up to ~2–3 weeks stable liver function
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes (perfusate from each well), measure albumin, urea, etc.
Readouts - TEER: Yes, can measure barrier or epithelial integrity if co-culture used
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: O₂, TEER, possibly other sensors for real-time monitoring
Perfused: Yes, built-in recirculating flow in each well
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Programmable flow rates & drug dosing in each of 96 wells
model_availability: Used in Draper’s internal or partner collaborations, not sold as a standalone kit

Organs/Tissues: Human renal proximal tubule epithelium (co-culture with endothelium possible)
Physiological/Pathological: Normal reabsorptive function; can model nephrotoxicity (drug-induced kidney injury)
Cell Source: Primary kidney epithelial cells or iPSC-derived renal cells in 3D microchambers
Multiple Cell Types: Yes if endothelium or fibroblasts are added for tubulovascular unit
Stromal Cells: Not standard but feasible (renal fibroblasts in interstitium)
Tissue-resident Immune: Possible but not typical in baseline model
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, can link to other organs (e.g. liver) on the same platform
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, collagen or basement membrane coatings on porous membrane
3D Scaffold: Yes, tubule-like structure under flow or 3D epithelium on membrane
Notable Features: Renal transporter function, dynamic fluid shear, measure toxicity or reabsorption
Plate/Format (Throughput): PREDICT96 multi-well, moderate-high throughput (96 parallel units)
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, can visualize tubule cell morphology, fluorescent transport assays
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, to measure reabsorbed vs. secreted compounds
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, fix/stain for transporters or tight junctions
Readouts - TEER: Yes, to gauge barrier tightness of tubule epithelium
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: O₂, TEER integrated, can measure permeability in real time
Dead Volume: Very low, ensuring accurate drug concentration
Perfused: Yes, recirculating flow in each well to mimic tubular fluid
model_availability: Used by Draper in collaborative R&D projects

Organs/Tissues: Human colon/intestinal epithelial barrier (primary stem-cell derived)
Physiological/Pathological: Healthy barrier function for drug absorption, can model inflammation (IBD-like) or infection
Cell Source: Primary human colon epithelial stem cells, 3D or monolayer on porous membrane
Multiple Cell Types: Yes if co-cultured with fibroblasts/immune cells; standard is epithelial
Stromal Cells: Optional sub-epithelial fibroblasts in separate channel for more realistic gut mucosa
Tissue-resident Immune: Possible to add if modeling inflamed gut, not default
Circulating Immune: No, not standard, though infiltration can be tested in advanced setups
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, can link to other organ chips (liver, etc.) to mimic gut-liver axis
Air-Liquid Interface: No, though some alveolar chips use ALI, but colon typically a fluid–fluid system with luminal flow
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, basement membrane or hydrogel around epithelial cells
3D Scaffold: Epithelial barrier forms a 2D monolayer, can form crypt-like structures in 3D expansions
Notable Features: High TEER values, stable differentiation ~11+ days, drug permeability testing
Max Culture Duration: ~2 weeks or more to see stable function
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, imaging cell morphology, tight junctions, etc.
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, measure secreted cytokines, drug absorption rates
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes, endpoint gene expression or microbial co-culture analysis
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, fix and stain entire barrier in each well
Readouts - TEER: Yes, integrated impedance sensors track barrier integrity
Perfused: Yes, recirculating flow over apical & basal channels for nutrient/gas exchange
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow/dosing per well programmable; can trigger inflammatory stimuli

Organs/Tissues: Human bronchial or alveolar epithelial cells, sometimes co-cultured with fibroblasts/endothelium
Physiological/Pathological: Healthy airway with mucociliary function; can simulate infection (e.g. SARS-CoV-2) or toxic inhalation
Cell Source: Primary human bronchial epithelial cells, iPSC-lung cells. ALI culture for mucociliary differentiation
Multiple Cell Types: Yes (epithelium + stromal or endothelial). Immune cells if inflamed model
Tissue-resident Immune: Not standard, but alveolar macrophages could be introduced
Circulating Immune: No, not standard unless multi-organ linking with flow of immune cells
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, can combine with other organs in PREDICT96
Air-Liquid Interface: Yes, apical side with air exposure, basal side with perfused medium
Extracellular Matrix: Epithelial layer on membrane with ECM coating
3D Scaffold: Pseudo-3D, cells form layered epithelium at ALI. Spheroids or alveolar bud also feasible
Notable Features: Mucociliary differentiation, infection studies (COVID-19 demonstration), real-time TEER for barrier
Plate/Format (Throughput): PREDICT96 plate, 96 microfluidic wells with ALI capability
Max Culture Duration: 1–3+ weeks, enough for full ciliation & infection assays
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, measure secreted mucus, cytokines, viral load if infected
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes at endpoint (scrape or detach epithelium)
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, fix & stain alveolar or bronchial layer on membrane
Readouts - TEER: Yes, barrier measurement for alveolar/airway integrity
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: TEER, possible O₂. Infectivity or mechanical sensors if custom
Perfused: Yes, basolateral perfusion while apical is air side
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator. Apical side is air, can introduce aerosol or pathogens
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow and dosing in each well programmable. Infectious agent introduction, etc.
model_availability: In-house at Draper or partner labs

Organs/Tissues: Human endothelial cells forming microvascular channels under shear
Physiological/Pathological: Normal vascular barrier or disease states (inflammation, permeability changes)
Cell Source: Primary human endothelial cells (HUVEC, microvascular) or iPSC-derived vascular cells
Multiple Cell Types: Can co-culture with pericytes or smooth muscle cells if desired
Tissue-resident Immune: No, though could add monocytes for adhesion/transmigration
Circulating Immune: Yes if perfused in the channel to study rolling/adhesion (similar to inflammation chip style)
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, can link to parenchymal organ modules on PREDICT96
Extracellular Matrix: Collagen- or fibronectin-coated membrane for endothelial adherence
Notable Features: Shear flow for physiological endothelium, measure vascular permeability or immune cell adhesion
Max Culture Duration: Days to ~2 weeks with stable barrier properties
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, watch cell alignment, morphology under flow
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, measure secreted cytokines, track flow outputs
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes, can be harvested for gene expression or protein assays
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, fix/stain endothelium in the channel
Readouts - TEER: Yes, measure endothelium tightness or barrier function
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: TEER, possibly O₂ or other sensors if used
Perfused: Yes, mechanical shear replicates blood flow
Real-time Microenvironment Control: User can vary flow rates, add immune cells or inflammatory stimuli

Organs/Tissues: Human gingival tissue (epithelial + fibroblasts + possibly immune) on-chip
Physiological/Pathological: Healthy oral mucosa or periodontitis-like inflammation under flow
Cell Source: Primary human oral epithelial cells, gingival fibroblasts, plus optional immune cells
Multiple Cell Types: Yes (3D co-culture of epithelial + fibroblast + optional immune support)
Stromal Cells: Yes, fibroblasts in sub-epithelial layer for normal gum tissue
Tissue-resident Immune: Possible inclusion of macrophages or dendritic cells for inflammatory models
Circulating Immune: No standard, but can be introduced if needed
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, if linking with other tissues in multi-organ approach
Air-Liquid Interface: Typically no, though partial ALI if simulating mouth surface; Draper references perfused but not full ALI
Extracellular Matrix: Epithelial layer on membrane with fibroblasts in collagen underneath
3D Scaffold: Yes, creating layered oral mucosa structure in 3D
Notable Features: Long-term viability (~28 days reported), responds to pro-inflammatory stimuli, mimics oral barrier function
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, can visualize epithelial layer, fibroblast interactions
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, measure inflammatory cytokines or secreted factors
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes, at endpoint for histology or gene expression
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, fix entire 3D oral tissue for morphological analysis
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: TEER, possibly O₂. Real-time monitoring of barrier changes
Perfused: Yes, media flow for nutrient supply/waste removal
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow/dosing changes, applying bacterial or inflammatory triggers
model_availability: Used by Draper & partners (e.g. Colgate-Palmolive) in R&D

Organs/Tissues: 3D human tumor microtissues (cancer cells ± stroma) in perfused microfluidic wells
Physiological/Pathological: Pathological (cancer). Testing drug efficacy, invasion, metastasis modeling
Cell Source: Patient-derived tumor cells, cell lines, or iPSC-derived tumor-like cells; co-culture with fibroblasts or endothelium optional
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, often tumor cells + stromal fibroblasts + optional endothelium
Stromal Cells: Yes, can add CAFs or normal fibroblasts for realistic tumor microenvironment
Tissue-resident Immune: Not standard, but can be introduced for immuno-oncology studies
Circulating Immune: No, unless specifically added for infiltration experiments
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, can be combined with other organ chips for metastasis or systemic toxicity
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, matrix (collagen, Matrigel) for 3D tumor growth
3D Scaffold: Yes, 3D spheroids or organoids in microchamber under flow
Notable Features: Perfused microenvironment for nutrient/drug delivery, can measure tumor growth, viability, invasion under real-time observation
Max Culture Duration: Days to ~2 weeks for typical tumor assay timelines
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes (confocal or plate-based imaging, measure size, invasion, viability)
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, track secreted factors, drug metabolism by tumor
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes, can retrieve tumor for endpoint molecular analysis
Readouts - TEER: No (unless endothelium is integrated to measure vascular barrier)
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Possible O₂ or pH sensors. Not default, but feasible
Dead Volume: Low microfluidic environment, ensuring local drug exposure
Perfused: Yes, recirculating flow feeding tumor microtissue
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow/dosing adjustable to mimic therapy schedules, can do combination treatments
model_availability: In-house development at Draper or collaborative partner usage
